Article.ArticleTitle: Influence of Post-UV/Ozone Treatment of Ultrasonic-Sprayed Zirconium Oxide Dielectric Films for a Low-Temperature Oxide Thin Film Transistor.

AbstractText: Solution-processed metal oxides require a great deal of thermal budget in order to achieve the desired film properties. Here, we show that the deposition temperature of sprayed zirconium oxide (ZrO<sub>x</sub>) thin film can be lowered by exposing the film surface to an ultraviolet (UV) ozone treatment at room temperature. Atomic force microscopy reveals a smooth and uniform film with the root mean square roughness reduced from ~ 0.63 nm (UVO-O) to ~ 0.28 nm (UVO-120) in the UV-ozone treated ZrO<sub>x</sub> films. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis indicates the formation of a Zr-O network on the surface film, and oxygen vacancy is reduced in the ZrO<sub>x</sub> lattice by increasing the UV-ozone treatment time. The leakage current density in Al/ZrOx/p-Si structure was reduced by three orders of magnitude by increasing the UV-ozone exposure time, while the capacitance was in the range 290-266 nF/cm<sup>2</sup>, corresponding to a relative permittivity (k) in the range 5.8-6.6 at 1 kHz. An indium gallium zinc oxide (IGZO)-based thin film transistor, employing a UV-treated ZrO<sub>x</sub> gate dielectric deposited at 200 °C, exhibits negligible hysteresis, an I<sub>on</sub>/I<sub>off</sub> ratio of 10<sup>4</sup>, a saturation mobility of 8.4 cm<sup>2</sup> V<sup>-1</sup>S<sup>-1</sup>, a subthreshold slope of 0.21 V.dec<sup>-1</sup>, and a V<sub>on</sub> of 0.02 V. These results demonstrate the potentiality of low-temperature sprayed amorphous ZrO<sub>x</sub> to be applied as a dielectric in flexible and low-power-consumption oxide electronics.
